CDC: STEPS YOU CAN TAKE IF A FAMILY MEMBER GETS ILL- Clean and disinfect high-touch surfaces daily in household common areas (e.g. tables, hard-backed chairs, doorknobs, light switches, remotes, handles, desks, toilets, sinks)
In the bedroom/bathroom dedicated for an ill person: consider reducing cleaning frequency to as-needed (e.g., soiled items and surfaces) to avoid unnecessary contact with the ill person.
As much as possible, an ill person should stay in a specific room and away from other people in their home, following home care guidance.
The caregiver can provide personal cleaning supplies for an ill person‚Äôs room and bathroom, unless the room is occupied by child or another person for whom such supplies would not be appropriate. These supplies include tissues, paper towels, cleaners.
If a separate bathroom is not available, the bathroom should be cleaned and disinfected after each use by an ill person. If this is not possible, the caregiver should wait as long as practical after use by an ill person to clean and disinfect the high-touch surfaces.

STUDENT TRAVEL: CDC provides recommendations on postponing or canceling travel. These are called travel notices and are based on assessment of the potential health risks involved with traveling to a certain area. A list of destinations with travel notices is available at https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/travelers/index.html.

The United States and most of the world is currently listed at Watch Level 1: CDC does not recommend canceling or postponing travel to destinations with level 1 travel notices because the risk of COVID-19 is thought to be low. If you travel, take the following routine precautions:

- Avoid contact with sick people.
- Avoid touching your eyes, nose, or mouth with unwashed hands.
- Clean your hands often by washing them with soap and water for at least 20 seconds or using an alcohol-based hand sanitizer that contains 60%‚Äì95% alcohol. Soap and water should be used if hands are visibly dirty.
- It is especially important to clean hands after going to the bathroom; before eating; and after coughing, sneezing or blowing your nose.

Staff at our Golden Hills campus recently completed Stop the Bleed Training, and are ready to step in during a bleeding emergency!

Stop the Bleed is a national awareness campaign and call-to-action intended to encourage bystanders to become trained, equipped, and empowered to help in a bleeding emergency before professional help arrives.

No matter how rapid the arrival of professional emergency responders, bystanders will always be first on the scene. A person who is bleeding can die from blood loss within five minutes, so it is important to quickly stop the blood loss. Those nearest to someone with life threatening injuries are best positioned to provide first care. We are glad that these staffers now have the training to step in if needed. #hopeweneverneedit

We are proud to award employee Aaron Johnson with the SCOE Superstar Award for his work that has far-reaching impact on education!
Earlier this year, Aaron researched a financial ratio that is commonly used to evaluate the fiscal health of private businesses and corporations. He took a deep dive in analyzing whether the ratio would be useful for schools districts. It turned out that with some modification, the ratio would be a good tool to measure the cash health of a district. So, Aaron and his team shared it with other counties through a subcommittee of the California County Superintendents Educations Services Association (CCSESA). We have received feedback from several County Offices of Education that the metric has been useful as a ratio to predict cash troubles in schools districts before they occur, helping districts keep their finances and student learning going in a positive direction. Awesome Superstar work Aaron!

SCOE administration was invited to be "Principal for a Day" at Sheldon Academy of Innovative Learning in Fairfield. The morning was filled with "wows" as we toured the new construction, funded by the voter-approved general obligation bond, including the new library, students center, and innovation lab (known as the iLAb). We also toured lots of classrooms, where teachers were incorporating innovative ideas and technology into lessons. Students were creating their own innovations and projects, making class engaging and bringing lessons to life; from kindergarten to eighth grade, students were involved in the learning! We look forward to visiting again soon to see more new construction and smiling faces. Thank you Fairfield-Suisun Unified School District for a great day.

Yesterday, more than 300 attendees from school site teams, law enforcement, and public safety agencies attended the Solano School Safety Symposium. The seminars were geared toward building our capacity as a community to understand behaviors, identify threats, and implement interventions and supports for students.

Agencies from Solano County, including the Solano County District Attorney, Krishna Abrams, Solano County Superintendent of Schools, Lisette Estrella-Henderson, Sheriff, Probation, and Health & Social Services partnered with the FBI and the Vacaville Police Department to bring data, research, science and systems to help assess threats and prevent school violence.

Schools, law enforcement, and mental health professionals must work together, each playing a critical role, in developing a proactive and preventive system of supports and interventions for our youth. Together we will make a difference in keeping kids safe and thriving!

Today, Solano educators shared about work happening for Solano students around science, technology, engineering, arts, agriculture, medical science, career technical education, equity, mental wellness, and workforce development (phew) at our 3rd Annual State of Education Forum Breakfast.

State Superintendent of Public Instruction, Tony Thurmond spoke to guests about closing the opportunity gap, student wellness, STEAM, and supporting education through funding. We are so appreciative of his support and participation in our forum.

We extend special thanks to the Rodriguez High School Jazz band, and Travis USD Color Guard for starting off our day with great music, a beautiful presentation of the colors, and a moving national anthem. It was all so awesome!

We also thank our forum sponsors, Brandman University and Travis Credit Union, for helping us share this important discussion with 51 elected officials, 56 educators and 26 business and city leaders from across Solano County. Together as a community, we will continue to make great opportunities happen for every student!
